- **Framework**: .NET 8.0 (Service), .NET 9.0 (Core/Persistence) - **Version mismatch needs fixing**
- AI Integration: Azure OpenAI API (planned with Microsoft.Extensions.AI)
- Database: MongoDB for job queue and persistence
- Logging: Serilog with Application Insights
- HTTP: Polly for retry policies
- Containerization: Docker

## Current Implementation Details

### Startup.cs References (Need Implementation):
- Background Services: JobProcessorBackgroundService
- Job Processing: IJobQueue, IJobProcessor, JobProcessorFactory
- External API Clients: ICrmTaskApiClient, IEmailApiClient, ISmsApiClient, IParsingApiClient, IContractInfoApiClient
- MongoDB: MongoDbContext, MongoJobQueue
- AI Processing: AiJobProcessor
- Code Processors: SendEmailProcessor, CreateCrmTaskProcessor, SendSmsProcessor

### Health Checks Configured For:
- MongoDB connectivity
- All external API endpoints
- Custom endpoint: /health/ready and /health/live

## Development Guidelines

### Immediate Next Steps:
1. Fix .NET Version Mismatch: Align all projects to .NET 8.0
2. Implement Core Domain Models: Create Job, JobResult, JobStatus, ProcessingMode entities
3. Implement Persistence Layer: Create MongoDB context and repositories
4. Implement Job Queue: Create IJobQueue implementation with MongoDB
5. Create Job Processors: Implement IJobProcessor interface for each job type
6. Add External API Clients: Implement clients for each external service
7. Create Test Projects: Add unit and integration test projects
8. Implement Background Service: Create the job processing background service

### Code Style:
- Follow .editorconfig rules (4 spaces, UTF-8 with BOM for C#)
- Use dependency injection for all services
- Implement comprehensive Serilog logging
- Add XML documentation for public APIs

## CI/CD Pipeline

### Jenkins Stages:
1. CI Stage: Build and test in Docker (currently no tests)
2. CD Stage: 
   - Build Docker image
   - Push to Azure Container Registry
   - Deploy to Development (automatic from develop branch)
   - Manual promotion to QA and Production

### Environment Variables:
- ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT: Development, QA, Production
- NUGET_AUTH_TOKEN: Required for private NuGet packages
- OPENAI_API_KEY: For AI processing (from Key Vault in production)

## Troubleshooting

### Build Issues:
- Ensure NUGET_AUTH_TOKEN is set for Docker builds
- Check .NET SDK version matches global.json (8.0)
- Verify all project references are correct

### Runtime Issues:
- Service will fail to start without MongoDB connection
- Health checks will fail if external APIs are not accessible
- Check appsettings for correct environment configuration

## Architecture Vision

The completed system will support:
- Hybrid Processing: Switch between code-based and AI-driven processing
- Job Types: Emai

message:
The Zone of Pain
Consider a component in the area of (0, 0). This is a highly stable and concrete
component. Such a component is not desirable because it is rigid. It cannot be
extended because it is not abstract, and it is very difficult to change because of
its stability. Thus we do not normally expect to see well-designed components
sitting near (0, 0). The area around (0, 0) is a zone of exclusion called the Zone
of Pain.
Some software entities do, in fact, fall within the Zone of Pain. An example
would be a database schema. Database schemas are notoriously volatile,
extremely concrete, and highly depended on. This is one reason why the
interface between OO applications and databases is so difficult to manage, and
why schema updates are generally painful.
Another example of software that sits near the area of (0, 0) is a concrete utility
library. Although such a library has an I metric of 1, it may actually be
nonvolatile. Consider the String component, for example. Even though all the
classes within it are concrete, it is so commonly used that changing it would
create chaos. Therefore String is nonvolatile.
Nonvolatile components are harmless in the (0, 0) zone since they are not likely
to be changed. For that reason, it is only volatile software components that are

Global and regional load balancing. Defines the scope of the load balancer. A global load balancer supports backends in multiple regions, whereas a regional load balancer supports backends in a single region. Even though the IP address of a regional load balancer is located in one region, a regional load balancer is globally accessible. You can distribute your backends in single or multiple regions to terminate connections close to your users and to meet your high availability requirements. To learn more, see global versus regional load balancing.

Routing of traffic in Premium Tier and Standard Tier. The load balancing services in Google Cloud come in different flavors depending on the network tier you choose, that is, Premium Tier or Standard Tier, with the former being more expensive than the latter. The Premium Tier leverages Google's high-quality global backbone whereas the Standard Tier uses the public internet to route traffic across the network. The network tier you choose depends on whether you prioritize cost or performance for your enterprise workload. Some load balancing services are only available in Premium Tier and not the Standard Tier. To learn more, see Premium versus Standard Network Service Tiers.

message:
Home Page - Solution Overview (0:30 - 1:30)

*[Navigate to home page]*

"This is Going-In, a blockchain ticketing system that can handle massive demand without crashes.

I chose blockchain for one critical reason: it eliminates the double spending problem. Each ticket is a unique NFT token, so duplicate sales are mathematically impossible.

But regular blockchains are too slow. That's why I'm using Arcology Network. Arcology processes transactions in parallel - thousands at the same time - reaching 10 to 15k TPS on production hardware.

The system uses three main components: smart contracts on Arcology for ticket sales, an Envio HyperIndex that tracks all blockchain events, and this React frontend that shows everything in real-time using GraphQL queries.
